title: SHO period and energy - metal strip and blocks

A stiff, flexible metal strip is held in a fixed clamp and is able to bend in the horizontal direction, as shown in Figure <math alttext="1" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn></math>. When a horizontal force of magnitude <math alttext="F" overflow="scroll"><mi>F</mi></math> is applied to the free end of the strip, the end is displaced a distance <math alttext="d" overflow="scroll"><mi>d</mi></math>. As is the case with a spring, <math alttext="F" overflow="scroll"><mi>F</mi></math> and <math alttext="d" overflow="scroll"><mi>d</mi></math> are proportional: <math alttext="F equals, k d" overflow="scroll"><mi>F</mi><mo>=</mo><mi>k</mi><mi>d</mi></math>, where <math alttext="k" overflow="scroll"><mi>k</mi></math> is a constant.

A group of students wish to experimentally determine the strip’s spring constant <math alttext="k" overflow="scroll"><mi>k</mi></math>. They have a collection of small metal blocks of different known masses. As shown in the top view in Figure <math alttext="2" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn></math>, each block can be attached to the end of the metal strip, and can then be made to oscillate as the strip bends back and forth. The students have access to a stopwatch, but do not have any way to measure force or mass. The weights of the blocks, by themselves, do not result in any measurable bending of the strip.

(b) For the data collected in the procedure from part (a), describe how the students could create a linear graph and how that graph could be analyzed to determine <math alttext="k" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>k</mi></math>.

A second group of students want to determine the spring constant <math alttext="k sub 2" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>k</mi><mn>2</mn></msub></math> for a second metal strip that is similar to the one shown in Figure <math alttext="1" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn></math>. The students have a collection of small blocks of different, known masses. The students also have a motion sensor that can measure both the maximum block speed and the amplitude of the oscillations. The students conduct five experimental trials using the different blocks, recording the oscillation amplitude and maximum block speed for each trial. The results of the experiment are shown in the table.

The students correctly determine that the relationship between <math alttext="M sub B" overflow="scroll"> <msub> <mi>M</mi> <mtext>B</mtext> </msub> </math>, \(A\), and \(v_{\max}\) is given by:

\(A^2=\frac{M_{\text{B}}}{k}v_{\max}^2\)

Where \(A\) is the oscillation amplitude, <math alttext="M sub B" overflow="scroll"> <msub> <mi>M</mi> <mtext>B</mtext> </msub> </math> is the mass of the block, and \(v_{\max}\) is the maximum speed of the block.
